verses.text: On my bed by night I sought the one whom my soul loves; I sought him, but did not find him.
verses.comment: The loved one is sought in solitude and longing, signifying the soul's search for union with its true beloved. Early Christian interpreters saw here an image of the soul seeking God, or even Mary Magdalene’s search for Christ (Jn 20:11-16). The search at night also hints at a tradition of spiritual desire, as in the Psalms (Ps 63:6).

verses.text: I will rise now and go about the city, in the streets and in the squares; I will seek the one whom my soul loves. I sought him, but did not find him.
verses.comment: The seeker leaves her comfort to look for her beloved, symbolizing an active pursuit of divine presence. Spiritual writers parallel this with seeking God earnestly, even in the busyness of life. Jesus’ parable of the lost coin reflects this persistent search (Luke 15:8-10).

verses.text: The watchmen who go about the city found me. I asked, 'Have you seen the one whom my soul loves?'
verses.comment: The watchmen resemble spiritual guides or leaders, whom the soul consults in her search. This hints at the importance of mediators or shepherds, and may also reflect the tradition of seeking guidance through the Church’s ordained ministers (cf. Acts 8:30-31).

verses.text: I had scarcely passed them when I found the one whom my soul loves. I held him and would not let him go until I had brought him into my mother's house, into the chamber of her who conceived me.
verses.comment: The beloved is found after passing the watchmen, showing that true union with God comes through earnest seeking and, subtly, through the home or 'house' of faith. The imagery of 'my mother’s house' symbolically points to the community where spiritual life began—ancient commentators often saw this as the visible Church, the mother of believers (Gal 4:26).

verses.text: I charge you, daughters of Jerusalem, by the gazelles or the does of the field, do not stir up or awaken love until it pleases.
verses.comment: A solemn charge to wait for the right timing of love represents the virtue of chastity and patience. In the spiritual sense, we await God’s self-revelation rather than forcing it. The reference to creation (gazelles/does) evokes order and harmony in divine timing (cf. Ps 127:2).

verses.text: Who is this coming up from the wilderness like columns of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, with all the merchant’s powders?
verses.comment: The procession evokes the Exodus imagery and the worship in the Temple (Exod 30:34-38). Myrrh and frankincense later signify Christ’s priesthood and sacrifice (Matt 2:11), connecting the text to messianic fulfillment.

verses.text: See, it is Solomon’s litter, with sixty mighty men around it, of the mighty men of Israel.
verses.comment: Solomon’s litter, protected by warriors, is an image of royal procession and security. Some Church Fathers saw the litter as signifying God’s dwelling on earth and the strong men as the apostles or defenders of the faith (cf. Ps 45:3-5).

verses.text: All of them are armed with swords, trained in war, each with his sword at his side, because of fear in the night.
verses.comment: These mighty men are ready for spiritual battle, recalling the call to put on the armor of God (Eph 6:17). The swords may symbolize the Word of God and the protection offered by faith.

verses.text: King Solomon made himself a carriage from the wood of Lebanon.
verses.comment: The carriage is a symbol of the king’s majesty—crafted from the best materials, like the Temple was. Spiritual readings see here the heavenly structure into which God gathers his people.

verses.text: He made its posts of silver, its back of gold, its seat of purple; its interior was inlaid with love by the daughters of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Precious materials in the construction parallel the tabernacle and the heavenly Jerusalem (Exod 25:3-7; Rev 21:18-21). Love, inscribed within, shows that at the heart of God’s dwelling is charity and unity—highlighting visible expressions of communal faith.

verses.text: Go out, daughters of Zion, and look upon King Solomon with the crown with which his mother crowned him on the day of his wedding, on the day of the gladness of his heart.
verses.comment: Solomon’s crowning and wedding is seen as foreshadowing the final King—the Messiah—in his wedding feast (Rev 19:7). The Church Fathers recognized here the mystical union between Christ and his people, seen in nuptial terms, calling the Church into joyful participation in the marriage supper of the Lamb.
